FacilityName: Ultramar Inc. d/b/a Valero Wilmington Refinery

_chemical.ChemicalName: Hydrogen fluoride/Hydrofluoric acid (conc 50% or greater) [Hydrofluoric acid]

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies

The Ultramar Inc d/b/a Valero Wilmington Refinery is submitting this RMP in accordance with the requirements stipulated in Final Rule of Risk Management Program Requirements Under Clean Air Act Section 112(r)(7); Amendments to the submission Schedule and Data Requirements; 82 FR 4696, January 13, 2017 and the California Accidental Release Prevention (CalARP) requirements (Title 19, California Code of Regulations, Division 2, Chapter 4.5). 



Since the last RMP submission, Valero Wilmington Refinery has had no significant upgrades to any process units. In this update, the inventory of regulated substances, 5-year accident history, offsite consequences analysis and prevention program have been reviewed and updated as well as the recalculation of process inventories. 



This RMP was prepared in accordance with the guidelines contained in the EPA's General Guidance on Risk Management Programs for Chemical Accident Prevention (40 CFR Part 68) and the California Accidental Release Prevention (CalARP) Program Guidance. The offsite consequence analysis was conducted in accordance with the EPA's RMP Guidance for Offsite Consequence Analysis. It was performed in accordance with the requirements stipulated in Final Rule of Risk Management Program Requirements Under Clean Air Act Section 112(r) (7); Amendments to the submission Schedule and Data Requirements, 82 FR 4696, January 13, 2017 and the CalARP regulations stipulated in California Health and Safety Code (H&SC) ?? 25531 to 25543.3. 



Stationary Source and Regulated Substances Handled

The Refinery operates a variety of processes to produce petroleum products, such as gasoline, diesel, and propane, from raw crude oil and raw gas oil. It is located in a heavy industrial area between the Ports of Los Angeles and Long Beach, approximately two miles north of Terminal Island; it employs 396 full time staff.



The Valero Wilmington Refinery is comprised of fort

y-eight process or utility units that are subject to the CalARP program 4 requirements. Additionally, seventeen of these units are also subject to the Federal RMP Program Level 3 requirements. The Refinery must submit a single RMP for the entire refinery; because it handles several listed regulated substances that exceed RMP and CalARP listed threshold quantities (TQ). The RMP and/or CalARP regulated substances handled above the TQ include various flammable mixtures, anhydrous ammonia, hydrogen sulfide (CalARP only), and modified hydrogen fluoride (HF) / HF acid.



In complying with OSHA PSM, EPA RMP Program Level 3, and CalARP program 4 requirements, the Refinery developed a Process Safety Risk Management System to address Accident Prevention and Emergency Response. Refinery managers and supervisors in process engineering, project design engineering, operations, maintenance, and safety have primary responsibility for implementation and maintaining element compliance. The process safety manager has the designated authority for integration and continuous audit of all RMP/CalARP elements.



Five-Year Accident History

In accordance with the RMP rule and CalARP regulation, an accidental release must be included in the RMP if it involves a regulated substance released from a covered process that results in death, injuries, or significant property damage onsite, or known offsite deaths, injuries, evacuations, shelter in place, property damage, or environmental damage. In the past five years, the Valero Wilmington Refinery has had no accidental release from a covered process that met these criteria. 



General Accident Release Prevention Program and Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps

The Refinery maintains a Process Safety and Risk Management System (PSRM), which was developed during the implementation of OSHA Process Safety Management (PSM). It is focused on preventing and minimizing the consequences of releases of toxic, flammable and explosive chemicals. Manager an

d Supervisor level responsibility for the PSRM system is divided into specific RMP Prevention Program element assignments. The following is a summary of the Process Safety and Risk Management System in place at the Refinery.



Employee Participation

Valero Wilmington Refinery employees participate in all areas of process safety management and accident prevention. Employee involvement is detailed in the Refinery's "Employee Participation Plan". Employees have access to information created as part of the Refinery process safety management and accident prevention program through manuals and electronic media.



Employee participation in RMP prevention program elements occurs through involvement, consultation and access to information. As standard business practice, employees participate in; PHAs, HCAs, DMRs, procedure development, MOCs, PSSRs, audits, routine Operations Area Team meetings and the Employee Health & Safety Committee process to monitor, evaluate and improve process safety. 



Further enhancing these systems, Valero employees have developed and utilize a Behavior Based Safety program which encourages job site observations and feedback to fellow employees regarding their safe work practices. Finally, in May of 2003, the Valero Wilmington Refinery became an OSHA Voluntary Protection Program (VPP) STAR site. As of this writing, the Valero Wilmington Refinery has received OSHA Voluntary Protection Program (VPP) STAR site recertifications in April 2008, April 2012, and August 2015. The star expired in August 2018 and is pending renewal in 2020. 



Process Safety Information

The Refinery maintains a variety of technical documents to ensure safe operation of each process. They address chemical properties and associated hazards, key process parameter limits and specific chemical inventories, and equipment design basis/configuration information. 



Hazardous chemical information, including exposure hazards, emergency response and exposure treatment, is provid

ed in safety data sheets (SDSs). This information is supplemented by reports and procedures that address corrosion and hazards of inadvertent chemical mixing. Employees are trained annually in the procedures of the "Wilmington Hazard Communication Instructional Plan", which provides information on processing and handling hazardous material.



Process technology information, including process flow diagrams, descriptions of process chemistry, maximum intended inventories and safe operating limits is available to all employees involved in operating or maintaining a process, either electronically or in manuals. Safety-related limits for specific process parameters (e.g., temperature, level, and composition) is documented and used in process hazard reviews to evaluate the consequences of process deviations. 



The Refinery maintains numerous technical documents that provide materials of construction, design pressure and temperature ratings, electrical rating of equipment and other information. This information, in combination with written procedures and trained personnel, provides a basis for establishing inspection and maintenance activities, as well as for evaluating proposed process and facility changes to ensure that process safety features are not compromised.



Process Hazard Analysis

The Refinery maintains a comprehensive program to ensure that process hazards are identified and controlled. Each process is systematically examined to identify hazards and ensure that adequate controls are in place. The semi-quantitative hazard and operability (HAZOP) analysis technique is primarily used to perform these evaluations during a PHA. It is conducted by a team of people with operating and engineering expertise to identify and evaluate process hazards and mitigation measures. 



PHA findings and recommendations are prioritized, recorded and tracked to resolution. Operations Area teams are responsible for addressing recommendations through projects, hardware, software,

procedural, and administrative control improvements. The final resolution is documented and retained. 



To ensure that process controls and/or process hazards do not deviate significantly from the original design safety features, the Refinery periodically updates and revalidates hazard analysis results. These periodic reviews are conducted at least every 5 years and will be conducted at this frequency until the process is permanently shut down.



Operating Procedures

The Refinery maintains written procedures, (available electronically via an internal Valero Wilmington Website), that address various modes of process operations, such as (1) unit startup, (2) normal operations, (3) temporary operations, (4) emergency shutdown, (5) normal shutdown, and (6) initial startup of a new process. These procedures are used as a reference by qualified operators and provide a basis for consistent training of new operators. Procedures are periodically reviewed and revised consistent with changes made through the "Management of Change Process" and are annually reviewed and certified as current and accurate.



In addition, Operating Limit and Consequences of Deviation documents are maintained, which specify response to exceeding upper or lower limits of process or equipment parameters.



Training

The Refinery has implemented a comprehensive training program for all employees involved in operating or maintaining a process. The program is described in the Refinery's "Training and Promotion Policy". New employees receive comprehensive new hire orientation and topic-specific training on all aspects of Refinery operations, including employee safety, environmental and safety compliance and basic process hazards overview.



Upon successful completion of training, new operators are paired with a senior operator to learn process-specific duties and tasks. After demonstrating the ability to perform the duties and tasks in a safe manner (e.g., through tests, skills demonstration), an

operator is allowed to work independently. All operators periodically receive refresher training, at least every 3 years.



Contractors

Refinery procedures ensure contractors perform work in a safe manner, have appropriate knowledge and skills, are aware of workplace hazards, understand what to do in an emergency, follow safety rules, and inform Refinery personnel of hazards encountered during their work. This is accomplished by providing contractors with (1) a process overview, (2) information on safety and health hazards, (3) emergency response plan requirements, (4) safe work practices prior to beginning work and (5) testing to ensure training is understood. 



Each contractor's safety program and performance are routinely evaluated to ensure they fulfill safety obligations.



Pre-startup Safety Reviews (PSSRs)

The Refinery conducts a PSSR for each facility modification that requires a significant change in process safety information. The purpose is to ensure safety features, procedures, personnel and equipment are appropriately prepared for startup prior to placing equipment into service. This review provides a final check to ensure construction is according to design specifications, procedures are in place, a hazard review was performed, and recommendations resolved, training of process unit employees completed and operational readiness of all supporting systems.



The Refinery PSSR procedure requires participation from hourly affected personnel with expertise in the process or equipment, engineering or technical and the asset owner, typically operations management.



Mechanical Integrity

The mechanical integrity program includes well-established practices and procedures to maintain pressure vessels, piping systems, relief and vent systems, controls and instrumentation, pumps and compressors, and emergency shutdown systems in a safe operating condition. The basic aspects of this program include: (1) training, (2) written procedures, (3) inspections and

test, (4) correcting identified deficiencies, and (5) applying quality assurance measures.



Training of maintenance personnel includes (1) an overview of the process, (2) safety and health hazards, (3) applicable maintenance procedures, (4) emergency response plans and (5) applicable safe work practices. 



Written procedures ensure work is performed consistently and provide a basis for training. Inspections and tests ensure equipment functions as intended and verify acceptable limits. Proactive service and data collection is performed by the Maintenance Equipment Reliability Department to ensure safe operation and high efficiency of process equipment.



Quality assurance measures are incorporated into equipment purchases and repairs to ensure suitability for intended use and proper materials and spare parts are used.



Safe Work Practices

The Refinery has long-standing safe work practices permits and procedures to ensure worker safety. Examples include control of the entry, presence and exit of support personnel; lockout-tagout to ensure isolation of energy sources during maintenance; safe removal of hazardous materials before opening process piping or equipment; control of spark-producing activities (i.e., hot work permit); and adequate precautions before confined space entry. 



Management of Change (MOC)

The Refinery MOC system requires that changes to items such as process equipment, chemicals, technology, procedures, and other facility changes be properly reviewed and authorized by Operations Area teams before implementation. 



Changes are reviewed to (1) ensure a sound technical basis, (2) consider potential impacts to safety & health, (3) verify that existing controls will not be compromised, (4) affected chemical hazard information, process operating limits, equipment information and procedures are updated, and (5) operating and maintenance personnel are provided necessary training.



Incident Investigation

Incidents that result, or could result

, in a fire/explosion, toxic gas release, major property damage, environmental loss or personal injury that require an investigation, have an investigation initiated within 48 hours. Facts are determined and corrective actions developed to prevent recurrence. The investigation team develops recommendations for resolution by Operations Area teams and Refinery Management. Corrective actions in response to a team's recommendations are tracked to completion by the Refinery HSE Department. Investigation results are reviewed with relevant employees and contractors; reports were historically retained for at least 5 years for use during PHA revalidation. Since 2017, reports are retained for the life of the process. 



Compliance Audits

The Refinery periodically conducts audits of the Process Safety and Risk Management System to ensure compliance with procedures and practices required by OSHA Process Safety Management. Audits are conducted at least every 3 years (PSM Tri-Annual audits). The audit findings are resolved by Operations Area teams and Refinery Management. Corrective actions are tracked until completion; final resolution of each finding is documented, and the three most recent audit reports retained.



CalARP requirements 

The Refinery has also implemented new programs with the 2017 CalARP regulations. This includes conducting "Damage Mechanism Reviews". This is an analysis of each corrosion or damage mechanism including review of process operating history and inspection records. Wilmington is on track to meet the 50% goal by 2020 and the 100% goal in 2022. 



Another new program is the "Hierarchy of Hazard Controls Analyses" in conjunction with Process Hazard Analyses. This is an analysis of each Major Incident scenario and consideration of the inherent safe design of the process. Wilmington is on track to meet the 50% goal by 2020 and the 100% goal in 2022. 



Wilmington completed the "Process Safety Culture Assessment" in 2018, including the final report,

and is implementing the corrective action plan. The "Human Factors Program" has been developed to include written checklists for required elements. Wilmington is on track to meet the 50% goal by 2020 and the 100% goal in 2022 for review of Operating and Maintenance Procedures. 

 

Wilmington has implemented evaluation forms and policies for items related to contractors, "Major Change" and "Major Incidents". Wilmington has implemented "Pre-Startup Safety Reviews" and documentation after turnaround and process shutdowns. 

 

Organizational changes that affect permanent staffing levels are managed with "Management of Organizational Change". The implementation of Corrective Actions work process has been expanded to include recommendations from new elements. 



Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps

Prevention program activities address equipment failures, human errors and PSRM system deficiencies.



In addition to these activities, the Refinery has safety features on many units to (1) contain and control a release, (2) quickly detect a release, and (3) reduce the consequences of a release. The specific safety features used are detailed in Section 7 in the RMP Data Elements.



Emergency Response Program Information

The Refinery maintains a written emergency response program to protect workers, the public and the environment. The program consists of procedures for responding to a regulated substance release. It addresses all aspects of emergency response, including first-aid and medical treatment, evacuation plans and accounting for personnel, notification of local emergency response agencies and the public and post incident cleanup and decontamination. In addition, the Refinery has procedures that address maintenance, inspection, and testing of emergency response equipment, as well as instructions that address their use. Employees receive training in these procedures as necessary to perform emergency response duties. The emergency response program is reviewed annuall

y and updated based on modifications made to Refinery processes or other Refinery facilities. 



The emergency response program is coordinated with the Los Angeles Fire Department (L.A.F.D). This provides a means of notifying the public, as well as facilitating quick response. The L.A.F.D. periodically participates in drills with the Refinery's emergency response team and is familiar with the Refinery and the hazardous materials in each process unit. In addition, the Refinery is a member of the "Mutual Aid Response Group" that consists of other local refinery emergency response teams, which would provide additional support if needed.



The Refinery conducts quarterly emergency drills that involve Refinery emergency response personnel. Periodic refresher sessions are conducted for the L.A.F.D. emergency responders regarding the hazards of regulated substances in the refinery.



Planned Changes to Improve Safety

Since early 2002 the Valero Wilmington Refinery has incorporated many enhancements and many significant investments to improve loss control and process safety management system performance in preparing for both certification and recertification under the OSHA Voluntary Protection Program (VPP) STAR site protocol. In 2008, Valero Wilmington made a capital commitment to modify the refinery's Hydrofluoric Alkylation process to use a less hazardous catalyst alternative. 



The refinery completed an Emergency Isolation Valve (EIV) project to remotely isolate "high hazard" pumps from their feed source in the event of a pipe leak/pump seal failure.



In addition, Wilmington refinery has been conducting "Safeguard Protection Analyses" in conjunction with Process Hazard Analyses since 2017. This is an analysis of the effectiveness of existing individual safeguards; the combined effectiveness of all existing safeguards for each failure scenario in the PHA; the individual and combined effectiveness of safeguards recommended in the PHA; and the individual and combin

ed effectiveness of additional or alternative safeguards that may be needed. This has resulted in a project to add additional instrumentation to dual seal configurations on "high hazard" pumps.



In addition, the Wilmington Refinery has been conducting "Hierarchy of Hazard Controls Analyses" in conjunction with Process Hazard Analyses since 2017. This is an analysis of each Major Incident scenario and consideration of the inherent safe design of the process. This includes a review of first order inherent safety measures, second order inherent safety measures, passive safeguards, active safeguards and procedural/administrative controls for the scenario. 



Prior to the 2018 Process Hazard Analyses, the Wilmington Refinery has been conducting "Damage Mechanism Reviews". This is an analysis of each corrosion or damage mechanism including review of process operating history and inspection records. This has increased proactive process monitoring or inspection procedures to prevent loss of containment incidents.  



The Refinery is committed to accident prevention and loss control through personnel training programs, considering safety in design, installation, operation and maintenance of processes and implementation of controls to prevent releases of regulated substances. However, if a release does occur, trained personnel will respond to control and contain the release in coordination with the Los Angeles Fire Department.
